overview_summary: All three neighboring landowners have no recorded public stance on the development or clean energy (all are classified as "unknown" stance). Each appears to have a low community profile with no evident official roles, indicating limited direct influence locally.

neighbors.name: Wade Waddle & Tiffany Waddle
neighbors.claims: The Waddle surname has deep roots in Saline County, with historical records noting a Samuel Waddle as a pioneering settler in the late 1800s [Kansas GenWeb Archives](https://www.ksgenweb.org/archives/1918ks/biow/waddlesh.html). Public records list Wade and Tiffany Waddle as landowners in Saline County, but they do not appear to hold any public office or participate in local civic boards [Saline County Board Records](https://bm-public-salinecounty.escribemeetings.com/BoardDetails/BoardInformation/13). No public statements or petition signatories regarding development or energy projects were found under the Waddles’ names in available county news and meeting archives [Saline County Board Records](https://bm-public-salinecounty.escribemeetings.com/BoardDetails/BoardInformation/13).
neighbors.influence_justification: No civic roles or public profile

approach_recommendations.engage: Given their low public profile, a respectful, neighborly outreach by a local peer (such as a fellow farmer or community liaison) is advised, focusing on listening to any concerns they may have.

neighbors.name: Justin D. Jensen
neighbors.claims: Justin D. Jensen is identified as a Saline County property owner, with no evidence of prominent community positions or public commentary on development issues [Saline County Board Records](https://bm-public-salinecounty.escribemeetings.com/BoardDetails/BoardInformation/13). He appears to be one of many local farmers (over 420 in the county received USDA subsidies in 2021) and does not stand out in local news or civic discussions [SE Illinois News](https://seillinoisnews.com/stories/655164698-farm-subsidies-plummet-in-2021-across-cities-in-saline-county). No mentions of Jensen’s involvement in any development-related meetings or petitions were found in Saline County media archives [Saline County Board Records](https://bm-public-salinecounty.escribemeetings.com/BoardDetails/BoardInformation/13).
neighbors.influence_justification: No civic roles or public profile

approach_recommendations.engage: Since Justin Jensen has not been publicly active on local issues, an informal one-on-one approach through a mutual acquaintance or neighbor is recommended, with transparent information about the project to build trust.

neighbors.name: Ronald A. Kinkelaar & Sandra K. Kinkelaar
neighbors.claims: Ronald and Sandra Kinkelaar own property in Saline County, according to county parcel records, but have a minimal public profile (no social or civic leadership roles found) [Saline County Board Records](https://bm-public-salinecounty.escribemeetings.com/BoardDetails/BoardInformation/13). Their names do not appear among prominent farm program recipients or local civic leaders, suggesting they are private landowners without public-facing activities [SE Illinois News](https://seillinoisnews.com/stories/655164698-farm-subsidies-plummet-in-2021-across-cities-in-saline-county). No evidence was found of the Kinkelaars taking any public stance or attending meetings related to development or clean energy in the area [Saline County Board Records](https://bm-public-salinecounty.escribemeetings.com/BoardDetails/BoardInformation/13).
neighbors.influence_justification: No civic roles or public profile

approach_recommendations.engage: A friendly introduction via a trusted community member would be suitable for the Kinkelaars. Given their low-key presence, approaching them privately and addressing any questions openly and patiently can help in understanding their perspective.
